name: Haiti
currentCrisisSummary:
Haiti endures a catastrophic **collapse of governance and society**, driven by centuries of **foreign intervention**, **economic extraction**, and **elite impunity**. A near-total implosion of state functions allows armed gangsâ€”funded by a **corrupt oligarchy** and empowered by the **'Core Group's'** political interferenceâ€”to control vast areas, imposing extortion, mass violence, and displacement.

An internationally backed, Kenyan-led mission faces constraints and contested legitimacy. The crisis is rooted in **colonial expropriation**, **odious debt enforced by France**, repeated **US occupations**, and **neoliberal policies** that deliberately undermined Haitian sovereignty, leaving the population extremely vulnerable.

colonialRoot.legacy: Haiti's fragility traces back to the international reaction to the **Haitian Revolution**. The world's first Black republic was isolated and pressured. In 1825 France imposed an **indemnity** ('compensation' for slaveholders). Financed by foreign loans, it drained resources and entrenched **dependency** â€” a key example of **post-colonial debt** perpetuating **extraction**.

historicalContext.title: US Occupation and Neoliberal Undermining
historicalContext.description: **Foreign interventions** repeatedly undermined sovereignty. The **US occupation** (1915-1934) centralised control and favoured **foreign interests**. Later **neoliberal** prescriptions (**tariff liberalisation** on US rice destroyed local farming, creating **food dependency**) weakened domestic agriculture, increasing reliance on imports and **external aid**.

historicalContext.title: Cold War Dictatorship and US Patronage
historicalContext.description: For decades (1957-1986), Haiti suffered the brutal, **kleptocratic Duvalier dictatorship**. As an anti-communist regime near Cuba, it was supported by the US as a **Cold War client**. This **imperial patronage** enabled terror and looting, hollowing out institutions.

historicalContext.title: The 'Core Group' and External Control
historicalContext.description: Since the 2004 coup, Haitian sovereignty has been systematically violated by the **'Core Group'** (ambassadors from US, France, Canada, etc.). This unaccountable body acts as a *de facto* shadow government, **hand-picking illegitimate leaders** (like Ariel Henry post-2021) and **dictating political outcomes** to serve foreign interests, ensuring state failure.

historicalContext.title: The UN Occupation (MINUSTAH) Legacy
historicalContext.description: The 2004-2017 UN 'stabilisation' mission (MINUSTAH) is a source of deep trauma. Beyond introducing the **2010 cholera epidemic** that killed thousands, the mission is infamous for its own legacy of **systematic sexual exploitation and abuse** and its use of **brutal military force** in urban slums (e.g., CitÃ© Soleil) to consolidate the post-coup government.

historicalContext.title: Oligarchic Control and Gang Warfare
historicalContext.description: The state is captured by a small, entrenched **economic oligarchy** that controls key sectors (imports, ports, energy). These elites fund and arm **paramilitary gangs** as a tool of terror to protect their monopolies, suppress popular dissent, and maintain a system of **impunity**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 5,600 killed (2024 alone) by gang violence fuelled by **oligarchic impunity** and **state collapse**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Approx. 6 million require aid due to instability and devastation imposed by **external actors** and local elites.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 5.7 million face acute hunger from **neoliberal policies destroying agriculture** and current gang blockades.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1.3 million internally displaced by gang terror enabled by **state failure**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands forced abroad by violence and desperation rooted in **foreign interference**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Health facilities non-functional due to attacks and breakdown caused by chronic **underfunding** and instability.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions lack safe water/sanitation due to infrastructure disintegration from historical **debt burdens** and state incapacity.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Disrupted
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands of children denied education due to insecurity and **state collapse**.

timeline.event: **The 'Pearl of the Antilles'**: Saint-Domingue becomes the most profitable colony in the Americas, producing vast sugar and coffee wealth built on the labour of enslaved Africans.
**Haitian Revolution**: Enslaved people and free Black insurgents overthrow colonial rule, culminating in independence and the world's first Black republic.

**French Indemnity**: Under threat of military action, Haiti agrees to pay France an indemnity to secure diplomatic recognition. The payments, financed with foreign loans, imposed a long-term fiscal burden on the new state.

**US Occupation**: US Marines occupy Haiti, centralise fiscal control, move reserves overseas and rework institutions in ways that served foreign commercial interests and weakened sovereign governance.

**Duvalier Dictatorship**: Backed by the US as a Cold War ally against communism, the brutal dictatorship of 'Papa Doc' and 'Baby Doc' Duvalier terrorises the population and loots the state for 29 years.

**Neoliberal Shock & Food Dependency**: Following the end of the dictatorship, IMF and US pressure forces Haiti to slash tariffs on imported rice. Subsidised US rice floods the market, destroying local agriculture and creating long-term food import dependency.

**Coup d'Ã‰tat**: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected president, is ousted in a coup with the backing of the US, France, and Canada, leading to a UN occupation (MINUSTAH). The **'Core Group'** is formed to manage the post-coup political order.

**Earthquake & Cholera**: A catastrophic earthquake kills over 200,000 people. In the disaster's aftermath UN peacekeepers (MINUSTAH) introduce **cholera** to Haiti, causing thousands of deaths. The mission is also documented for **systematic sexual abuse** and **violent repression**.

**Assassination of President MoÃ¯se**: The killing of Jovenel MoÃ¯se deepens political instability. The **'Core Group'** intervenes to install the unelected Ariel Henry as de facto ruler, accelerating the collapse of state legitimacy.

**Gang Siege and International Mission**: Violent gang campaigns seize large parts of Port-au-Prince, triggering mass displacement and extreme suffering. A Kenyan-led, UN-backed mission deploys amidst controversy over its mandate and legitimacy.

donate.description: A Haitian organisation providing financial inclusion, livelihoods and community development services to rural families.

advocacy.title: Demand Reparations from France
advocacy.description: Demand financial reparations and a serious, public accounting from France for the harms and long-term economic damage caused by the 1825 indemnity.

advocacy.title: Dismantle the 'Core Group'
advocacy.description: Oppose all external interventions that undermine Haitian sovereignty, starting with the demand to **dismantle the neo-colonial 'Core Group'** and respect the Haitian-led **Montana Accord**.

advocacy.title: Support Food Sovereignty
advocacy.description: Support Haitian-led peasant movements and campaigns for food sovereignty and oppose trade and aid policies that privilege imports over local agriculture.

advocacy.title: Demand UN Accountability
advocacy.description: Push for full accountability and **reparations** for the UN's role in the **cholera epidemic** and the **sexual exploitation** committed by MINUSTAH peacekeepers.

advocacy.title: Sanction the Oligarchy
advocacy.description: Demand targeted international sanctions on the Haitian **oligarchy** and politicians who **fund and arm gangs**.

reading.title: *The Black Jacobins: Toussaint L'Ouverture and the San Domingo Revolution*
reading.description: C. L. R. James's classic Marxist history of the Haitian Revolution and its global anti-colonial significance.

reading.title: *The Uses of Haiti*
reading.description: Paul Farmer's devastating critique of US imperialism, structural violence, and failed international policy in Haiti over decades.

reading.title: *Damming the Flood: Haiti, Aristide, and the Politics of Containment*
reading.description: Peter Hallward's critical analysis of the 2004 coup against Aristide and the international forces undermining Haitian sovereignty.
